abstract.p: A two-degree-of-freedom piezoelectric motor using only one piezoelectric ceramic was proposed based on two vibration modes (B32 and B23) of a rectangular plate piezoelectric vibrator. The working principle was elaborated. Analytical and numerical models were established in order to design the piezoelectric vibrator. Calculations with finite element method were carried out using ANSYS software to validate the analytical models and demonstrate the elliptical trajectory of the four contact points between the stator and the sphere. Experimental result on the prototype shows that the numerical result including resonance frequency and elliptical motion of the motor indicate good agreement with the experimental one. The rotation speed around an axial along the direction of length of the rectangular piezoelectric vibrator of the motor is 37.7 r/min under the drive voltage 90 V and excitation frequency 44 kHz.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Single-degree-of-freedom (DOF) motors (including rotary and linear motions) and their control systems have been widely and thoroughly researched in both theory and practice. However, an ever-growing sophistication of electromechanical systems, especially the high-performance requirements of precision devices such as robot joint and camera systems, require more than that the single-DOF motors can provide [1]. A common way of achieving N degrees of freedom is to have N single DOF motors. Each of them is independently responsible for one dimension of motion, which can be either translation or rotation. Nevertheless, it would not only increase the length of kinematic chain but also lead to more accumulated errors, which bring about a negative impact on the positioning accuracy and stability. Compared with the single-DOF motor, multi-DOF motor has superiorities in high integration in structure and high efficiency in the utilization of materials and components, which gain it a wide application in the multi-DOF instruments.

Piezoelectric driving technology has greater potential in the field of multi-DOF motor compared with electromagnetic drives. By avoiding bulky coils, piezoelectric drives are simple in structure and diverse in forms. It neither produces electromagnetic interference nor is influenced by external electromagnetic interference. Meanwhile, it has more advantages in high power density and easy control compared with other functional materials such as shape memory alloy, magnetostrictive, and electrostrictive and artificial muscles. Consequently, a variety of multi-DOF piezoelectric ultrasonic motors have been developed in recent decades. Zhang et al. [2] presented a development of a two-degree-of-freedom rotary-linear actuator using three piezoelectric stacks to achieve high driving force and torque. Shigeki and Shigeki [3] designed a spherical ultrasonic motor, in which three or four ring-shaped vibrators were arranged around a spherical rotor. Ting et al. [4] proposed a hemispherical shell stator, with a series of surface-shaped piezoelectric ceramic bonded on three orthogonal circle-sections of the shell, to drive the three-DOF rotational sphere. Takemura and Maeno [5] realized three-DOF motions of a spherical rotor actuated by a single-cylinder stator using three circular piezoelectric ceramic. Multi-DOF motor constructed with similar cylinder stator was also studied by Zhao and Li [6, 7]. By attaching piezoelectric elements on the periphery of a square bar-shaped stator, multi-DOF piezoelectric ultrasonic motors were constructed by Vasiljev et al. [8] based on ‘shaking beam’ actuator principle, Khoo et al. [9] via flexural-axial coupled vibration, and Zhang et al. [10] using in-plane deformation of planar piezoelectric elements, respectively.

Multi-DOF motors with plate stator were also proposed. At present, these types of spherical motors are more compactable than others. Aoyagi et al. [11] designed a multi-DOF thick-film ultrasonic motor based on three bending resonance modes of a thin alumina square plate. These modes were excited by five thick-film PZT elements. Takemura and Maeno [12] developed a multi-DOF ultrasonic motor. The resonance modes of their motor were excited by three groups of piezoelectric elements arranged in double cross. Otokawa and Maeno [13] constructed an ultrasonic motor composed of four arrayed-type vibrators and a spherical rotor, in which each vibrator had three patterns of vibration modes that can be appropriately combined to make the rotor rotate around three axes.

These motors mentioned above are based on multi-pieces of piezoelectric elements and the number of piezoelectric ceramic is no less than that of the degrees of freedom. For instance, if three degrees of freedom are expected, three or more piezoelectric elements should be employed. Multi-pieces of piezoelectric elements make the motors structurally complex and inconvenient to fabricate, and require a drive source containing at least three phases or triple channels for their operation.

In this study, a two-degree-of-freedom piezoelectric motor with plate stator using only one piezoelectric element is proposed. It is shown that the motor, excited by the single piezoelectric element, can form more than one DOF motion via appropriate structure and vibration modes. In this article, the working principle of the motor is explained. The analytical calculations for the dimensions of the proposed motor, which have not been discussed in detail in current literatures, are carried out. Then, the motion mechanism is proved through the finite element analysis of the motor's piezoelectric vibrator. Finally, the prototype test is explained.
There are many potential applications for this type of piezoelectric motor, including robot ball joints, omnidirectional wheels, or optical devices.

sec.title: 2.1 Structure
sec.p:
Figure 1 illustrates the structure of the motor. The rectangular plate stator is composed of a monolithic piezoelectric and a metal substrate. The piezoelectric ceramic is uniformly polarized in the thickness direction, and bonded at the bottom of the rectangular substrate with conductive epoxy. The sphere is placed on four protrusions of the stator. The function of the protrusions will be discussed later. The length and width of the piezoelectric ceramic are slightly smaller than those of the substrate in order to obtain a better electromechanical coupling coefficient for the piezoelectric vibrator. As is shown in Fig. 1, the length direction of the stator is defined as the x-axis, the width direction as the y-axis, and the thickness direction as the z-axis, and the four protrusions are numbered for convenience. The piezoelectric motor is driven by standing-wave which is easy to feed [14, 15]. B23 and B32 vibration modes of the rectangular stator are selected. The dashed lines shown in Fig. 1 refer to the nodal lines of the B23 mode. The protrusion Nos 1 and 3 are located on the crossing points of the middle nodal line in the x-direction and two nodal lines in the y-direction of B23 mode, as shown in Fig. 1. The protrusion Nos 2 and 4 are located on the intersections of the middle nodal line in the y-direction and two nodal lines in the x-direction of B32 mode, as shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 1
Geometry of the two-DOF piezoelectric motor Fig. 2
Nodal lines of the piezoelectric vibrator and impact directions on protrusions at B32 vibration mode

sec.title: 2.2 Working principle
sec.p: The basic principle of piezoelectric ultrasonic motor is based on the inverse piezoelectric effect of piezoelectric material. When an alternate electric field is applied across the piezoelectrics, the materials produce a very low strain which encourage the stator generating resonance. The vibration of the stator promotes the particles on the surface of the stator to form closed curve movements (usually elliptical motion) which drive the rotor and the load of the piezoelectric ultrasonic motor. Hence, the key issue of designing a new ultrasonic motor is to obtain elliptical motion for the particles. If multi-degree-of-freedom motions of the motor are required, different elliptical motions in different vibration states should be formed. The elliptical motions of the motor presented in this article are actuated by two types of the stator's vibration modes.

When the substrate vibrates at B32 mode, the four protrusions swing around the nodal line within a small angle range. The force direction that the substrate exerts on the protrusions in a certain half cycle is shown with arrows in Fig. 2. Protrusion Nos 2 and 4 are forced in four directions, which result in twisting and limit their deformations in the horizontal direction. Protrusion Nos 1 and 3 are forced only in x-direction, and the displacement produced in x-direction is larger than that of protrusion Nos 2 and 4. Theoretically, there are no vertical displacements of the four protrusions when they are placed on the nodal lines. However, due to the thickness of the protrusions and the dimension design specification of the piezoelectric vibrator which will be discussed in Section 3.2, the protrusions cannot be placed exactly on the nodal lines, which results in small vertical displacements of the four protrusions. Combining the horizontal and vertical displacements, the elliptical trajectories of protrusion Nos 1 and 3 are shown in Fig. 3(a), and protrusion Nos 2 and 4 shown in Fig. 3(b). Comparing the elliptical motions shown in Fig. 3(a) with those in Fig. 3(b), the displacement in x-direction in Fig. 3(a) is much larger than that in Fig. 3(b). Hence, the protrusion Nos 1 and 3 can be treated as the drive-foot and the protrusion Nos 2 and 4 as the support-foot since the deformations of the protrusion Nos 2 and 4 are relatively small, and the sphere is mainly driven by the protrusion Nos 1 and 3. The protrusion Nos 1 and 3 move along the elliptical trajectories synchronously to drive the sphere rotating around the y-axis. Fig. 3
The formation of elliptic motions: (a) a combination of a horizontal bending and a vertical vibration and (b) a combination of a horizontal swing and a vertical vibration

Similarly, at B23 mode, the sphere is supported by the protrusion Nos 1 and 3, and driven by the protrusion Nos 2 and 4 rotating around the x-axis. From the microscopic point of view, the protrusions actuate the sphere step by step. The interval between every two adjacent step is very short (usually no more than 0.1 ms) due to the high excitation frequency. Therefore, from the macroscopic point of view, the sphere forms a continuous rotation. In this way, by means of the B23 and B32 modes, two rotation degrees of freedom around the two orthogonal axes of a sphere can be achieved using the single piezoelectric element.

sec.title: 2.3 Elliptical motion of the contract point
sec.p: The creation of elliptical motion, which is essential for driving the rotor to form an oriented and continuous rotation, is presented in the following subsection.

The vibration energy of the whole piezoelectric vibrator is mostly distributed in the substrate since the substrate is directly excited by the ceramic and is much larger than protrusions in size and volume. Therefore, a hypothesis that the ceramic encourages the substrate that subsequently encourages the protrusions can be proposed. The protrusions and the substrate are integrated constructed; so the protrusion can be regarded as a cantilever beam with one end simply supported on the substrate, and the other end free.

Protrusion marked with dotted line in Fig. 4 represents the initial position of the protrusion. Protrusion marked with dashed line illustrates the protrusion's rigid inclination together with the substrate's vibration. Also, protrusion marked with solid line demonstrates that protrusion produce bending deformation besides rigid inclination. The vibration process of the protrusion is divided into two stages: the rigid inclining and the first-order bending as a cantilever. Fig. 4

sec.title: 3.1 Analytical Formulation
sec.p:

The composite piezoelectric vibrator composed of piezoelectric ceramic and metal substrate is taken as a homogeneous isotropic plate with a uniform length of a and a width of b for convenience. The heterogeneous characteristics in the thickness direction are expressed by equivalent parameters. Substituting (16) into (1), then inserting (1) into (13) and (14), and substituting the results into (15), yield an algebraic equation about Amn. The nonzero solution for Amn is (18) where
The frequency coefficient λmn and its corresponding angular frequency ωmn can be calculated according to (18). Then, the resonance frequency of the piezoelectric vibrator can be expressed as (19)

The resonance frequencies of piezoelectric vibrator at B23 and B32 modes, and the relationship between resonance frequency and the structural dimensions of piezoelectric vibrator (including the length of a and the width of b of the piezoelectric vibrator; the thicknesses hb and hc of the substrate and the piezoelectric ceramic, respectively) can be obtained by (19).

If the piezoelectric vibrator is a square plate (a equals to b), the excitation frequencies of B32 and B23 modes are approximately the same, and the vibration shapes of the two modes would be difficult to be distinguished. Thus, a rectangular plate with different length and width is adopted. However, if the aspect ratio a/b of the rectangular plate is much greater than 1, there would be an intermediate vibration mode between the B32 and B23 modes. When the motor is converted between B32 and B23 modes, the frequency adjustment would excite the intermediate vibration mode, and lead to the generation of needless movement for the motor. The consequence is that the motor cannot be adjusted accurately and smoothly, which should be avoided during the process of mode conversion. Hence, proper length and width of the piezoelectric vibrator should be determined to ensure that there are no other vibration modes involved between the B32 and B23 modes.

sec.title: 3.2 Position of the protrusion
sec.p: The position where the protrusion located on the substrate is crucial for the sphere to move as the designed motion. Based on the beam function combination method, free–free unidirectional slab function in both x- and y-directions is introduced to investigate the node and loop of the unidirectional slab where the protrusions located.

The shape functions of free–free unidirectional slab are the same as those in (17). There are (n − 1) nodes for the shape function φn. When n = 3, the unidirectional slab works at the second-order vibration mode, the position of the nodes are at 0.224 l and 0.776 l. When n = 4, the unidirectional slab works at the third-order vibration mode, the position of the nodes are at 0.132 l, 0.5 l, and 0.868 l. Since piezoelectric vibrator may work at B23 or B32 mode, the unidirectional slab in both x- and y-directions should work at second- or third-order vibration mode. Figure 5 illustrates the nodes and vibration shapes of the unidirectional slab, the dashed lines denote the vibration shape of the unidirectional slab in x- and y-directions while piezoelectric vibrator works at B32 mode. The dash dot lines indicate the vibration shape of the unidirectional slab in x- and y-directions while piezoelectric vibrator is in the mode of B23. Fig. 5
Vibration shapes of unidirectional slab at second and third orders: (a) slab in y-direction and (b) Slab in x-direction

According to the working principle of the motor, the protrusions locate on two nodes and an intermediate antinode of the second-order vibration shape, and three nodes of the third-order vibration shape. The intermediate antinode at second-order vibration shape coincides with the intermediate node at third-order vibration shape, as shown in Fig. 5, at 0.5 l. Protrusion at this position mainly acts as the drive-foot. Error exists between the two nodes at second-order vibration shape and the two border nodes at third-order vibration shape (that is 0.132 l and 0.224 l, 0.776 l, and 0.868 l). Protrusion at this position mainly acts as the support-foot. In order to ensure the balance and rotating effect of the sphere, the spacing between the two sets of symmetrically arranged protrusions should be equal, and the protrusions should be located proximately at the nodes or antinodes. However, due to the unequal length and width of the piezoelectric vibrator and the position deviation of nodes between second- and third-order vibration shapes, protrusions cannot be located right at the nodes. Hence, the position of the protrusions is determined by a guideline that the deviation should be the least. sec.title: 3.3 Dimensions of the protrusion
sec.p: As analysed in Section 2.3, the dimensions of the protrusion should be designed to make the bending vibration frequency of the protrusions in accordance with the entire vibration frequency of the piezoelectric vibrator. Moreover, excellently high mechanical strength should be possessed, so that the sphere can be effectively supported and wear rate can be greatly reduced. For each vibration frequency of the four protrusions, protrusion Nos 1 and 3 should be in accordance with the frequency of B32 mode, and protrusion Nos 2 and 4 in accordance with B23 mode.

According to the modal of Bernoulli–Euler beam, the formula for the resonance frequency of the protrusion is given as (21) where βnlp can be solved from cos βnlp × cosh βnlp = −1; lp is the height of the protrusion, or namely the length of the cantilever beam. For protrusion that vibrates in the thickness direction, (21) can be expressed as (22) where hp is the thickness of the protrusion. According to (22), the vibration frequency of the protrusion decreases with the increasing height of the protrusion. The four protrusions should be higher enough to prevent the sphere from contacting the substrate. For a sphere with radius of r, the height of protrusions should be lp > r-r2-s2/4. To guarantee the bending vibration frequencies of protrusion Nos 1 and 3 and protrusion Nos 2 and 4 matching the vibration frequencies of B32 and B23 modes respectively, the thickness hp of protrusion Nos 1 and 3 should be different from those of Nos 2 and 4. If the height of protrusions is confirmed, the thickness of the four protrusions can be calculated by (23) where ω32 and ω23 are calculated by (19).The horizontal deformation of the tip of protrusion exists in height and width directions of the protrusion. Displacement in width direction should be relatively small to minimize the influence on the rotation of the sphere around two orthogonal axes. When the protrusion swings in the width direction, (21) can be expressed as (24) where wp is the width of the protrusion. Comparing (22) with (24), the value of the width of protrusion should be larger than that of its thickness, so that the bending vibration frequency of the protrusion in the width direction could be higher than the working frequency of piezoelectric vibrator, and the protrusion in the width direction acts only as a lever. However, if the width of protrusion is too large, the vibration shape of piezoelectric vibrator in the width direction may be affected. Summarizing the above factors, the width of the protrusions is taken by 2hp ≤ wp ≤ 0.552 b/3.

sec.title: 4.1 Finite element method modelling
sec.p: Finite element method (FEM) is used to analyse the rectangular plate piezoelectric vibrator and verify the theoretical analysis of the working principle. The finite element model of the piezoelectric vibrator is established in ANSYS 10.0.

The structural dimensions are determined based on the design and calculation methods presented in Section 3. The substrate of the piezoelectric vibrator is made of stainless steel, and PZT-4 with 1 mm thickness is chosen as the piezoelectric layer. The motor is designed to drive a sphere with a diameter of 25.4 mm. The length of the substrate is a = 30 mm, and the spacing between the protrusions s = 17.5 mm. Other dimensions of the prototype are shown in Table 2. The volume ratio of the sphere and the piezoelectric vibrator is 276 per cent. Table 2

Width (mm) 22 25 4 4
Thickness (mm) 1 1 1.2 1.15

SOLID5 elements are used for the piezoelectric layer and SOLID95 elements for the substrate layer. SOLID5 is a hexahedral-coupled element with four degrees of freedom (ux, uy, uz, volt) at each node. SOLID95 is a structural element adapted to both tetrahedral and pyramidal units. The tetrahedral units are used to model the substrate layer; the pyramidal units are used as the transition elements between the tetrahedral and hexahedral elements. Each node of SOLID95 element has three degrees of freedom (ux, uy, uz). The volt degrees of freedom of the nodes at the top and bottom surfaces of the piezoelectric layer are coupled so that all nodes at the electrodes have the same electrical potential.

Modelling of the piezoelectric layer is based on the e-type piezoelectric constitutive equations [18] (25) where {T} and {S} are stress and strain vectors; {D} and {E} the electric displacement and electric field, respectively; [c] the elastic constants; [e] the piezoelectric stress constants; and [ε] the dielectric constant.

After the piezoelectric layer is discrete, the coupled finite element equation for every discrete piezoelectric element is (26) where {U} and {Φ} are the nodal displacement and electric potential vectors, respectively; {F} and {Q} the node force and the charge vectors, respectively; [Muu] the mass matrix derived from density and volume; [Kuu] the mechanical stiffness matrix derived from elasticity matrix; [Kuφ] the piezoelectric stiffness matrix, derived from piezoelectric matrix; and [Kφφ] the dielectric stiffness matrix derived from dielectric matrix. Structural damping matrix [Cuu] is defined as the linear combination of mass matrix [Muu] and mechanical stiffness matrix [Kuu] (27) where the variables α and β are the Rayleigh damping coefficients.

sec.title: 4.2 Resonance frequency calculation
sec.p:
Modal analysis is executed to investigate the resonant frequency and vibration shape of the piezoelectric vibrator. Modal extraction method uses Block Lanczos. According to the vibration shapes of the modal analysis results, the 17th vibration mode meets the B32 mode of the rectangular plate piezoelectric vibrator, and its excitation frequency is 43.323 kHz; the 18th mode conforms to the B23 mode with excitation frequency of 43.565 kHz. The excitation frequencies of the 16th and 19th modes are 40.715 and 44.900 kHz, respectively. It is followed that the rectangular plate piezoelectric vibrator distinguishes the excitation frequency of B32 and B23 modes effectively, and there are no other vibration modes between these two modes. The vibration shape of B32 mode is shown in Fig. 7(a), and B23 mode in Fig. 7(b). Taking protrusion Nos 1 and 3 as a group and protrusion Nos 2 and 4 as the other group, it can be seen from the deformation diagram that the deformation of one group is much larger than the other of the two groups. Fig. 7
Deformation diagram of: (a) B32 vibration mode at 43.323 kHz, (b) B23 vibration mode at 43.565 kHz

sec.title: 4.3 Trajectory analysis
sec.p: Transient response calculated by ANSYS 10.0 is conducted to verify the working principle analysis. The contact points between the stator and rotor, that is the tip of four protrusions, are chosen for analyse. The points on protrusion Nos 1 to 4 are defined as D1, D2, D3, and D4, respectively.

The Rayleigh damping coefficients α and β should be identified in transient analysis as described in (27). Rayleigh damping coefficients are applied to the entire structure, while the rectangular plate is composed of two components. In order to reflect the actual situation, the coefficients are determined by the condition that the simulation results match the experimental data [19]. The displacement of geometric centre point of the rectangular piezoelectric vibrator is tested with an excitation voltage of 50 V, frequency of 43.565 kHz. Then, the coefficients α and β are adjusted so that the simulation is consistent with the experimental results. Eventually, the Rayleigh damping coefficients used in transient analysis are α = β = 3.04 × 10−7.

The maximum excitation frequency fh applied to the motor is 43.565 kHz, then the time step is taken as Δt = 1/(20fh) = 1.15 × 10−6 s. Coefficient β mainly acts on the damping when the rectangular plate is in high-frequency vibration; the viscous damping ratio of the structure is taken as ξ = πfhβ = 0.042. The observation time for transient analysis is set as ts = 1/(3ξfh) = 1.84 × 10−4 s. Then, the number of the steps is ns = ts/Δt = 160. To investigate the steady-state response of piezoelectric vibrator, the total number of analysis steps should be increased and taken as nt = 3 ns = 480.

The B32 mode of the rectangular plate is analysed in the following; the vibration of B23 mode is similar to B32 mode. When solving each load step, the voltage applied to the piezoelectric layer is Vn = Volt × sin(2π × f × tn), where tn is the time of nth load step, Volt is taken equal to be to 50 V, and f is equal to 43.323 kHz.

When the rectangular plate resonates steadily at B32mode, the vibration deformations of D1–D4 in xyz directions are shown in Fig. 8. Figure 8(a) illustrates the motion curve in the x-direction of the fourcontact points. D1 and D3 move synchronously in same direction; the maximum displacement is1.2 × 10−7 m; D2 and D4 move synchronously inthe reverse direction, the maximum displacement is 2.9 × 10−10 m. The displacement of D2 and D4 isonly 0.24 per cent of that of D1 and D3 in the x-direction. Compared with D1 and D3, D2 and D4 can be treated statically, which is consistent with the theoretical analysis of the working principle in Section 2.2. Fig. 8
The comparison of displacement values of four contact points at B32 vibration mode: (a) in the x-direction, (b) in the y-direction, and (c) in the z-direction

Figure 8(b) and (c) shows the motion curve of the four contact points in the y- and z-directions, respectively. D2 and D4 move synchronously and reversely in the y-direction, while their displacements are undulating. This is because there is a minor deviation between D2, D4 and the nodal line; the deviation causes the unequal vibration in forward and backward directions. The maximum displacement of D2 and D4 in the y-direction is 2.6 × 10−8 m, while the maximum displacement of D1 and D3 in the y-direction is 3.9 × 10−10 m. Compared with D1 and D3, D2 and D4 can be treated as being static. This is because the stiffness in the width direction is better than that in the thickness direction, and the larger width restricts the swing of protrusions. D1 and D3 move consistently in the z-direction with the maximum displacement of 1.0 × 10−7 m; the motion direction of D2 and D4 is opposite to that of D1 and D3 with their maximum displacement of 2.1 × 10-8 m in the z-direction. There are phase shifts between the displacement of D1 or D3 in x- and z-directions, as discussed in Section 2.3.

Comparing the results mentioned above, the displacement of D1 and D3 in the y-direction is about 0.325 per cent of that in the x direction, and 0.39 per cent in the z-direction. This indicates that D1 and D3 mainly oscillate in the x and z-directions and the movement in the y-direction can be ignored; the elliptical trajectories of D1 and D3 are mainly formed by the movements in the x- and z-directions. For D2 and D4, the displacement in x-direction is approximately 1.12 per cent of that in the y-direction, and 1.38 per cent in the z-direction. Therefore, the elliptical trajectories of D2 and D4 are mainly formed by the movements in the y- and z-directions.

Comparing the movements between D1, D3 and D2, D4, the superposition displacement of the elliptical trajectory of D2, D4 is about 22 per cent of the size of D1, D3. This indicates that when the rectangular plate vibrates under B32 mode, D1 and D3 drive the sphere and D2 and D4 can be used as the support points. Furthermore, D2 and D4 move reversely to D1 and D3 in the z-direction, which increases the relative travel distance of D1 and D3 in the z-direction, and enhances the drive capability of the protrusion Nos 1 and 3.

The elliptical trajectories of the four contact points combined by the displacement in xyz-directions are shown in Fig. 9. Good elliptical trajectories are formed in the main xoz plane for D1 and D3. D2 and D4 move exactly in the xoz plane, but dispersedly in the xoy and yoz planes. This is mainly due to the displacement fluctuation in the y direction. D1 and D3 move in the same direction; rotating the sphere simultaneously, while D2 and D4 move in the reverse direction. These results are consistent with the theoretical analysis on the working principle for the motor. Fig. 9
The elliptical trajectories of four contract points at B32 vibration mode: (a) No. 1 protrusion, (b) No. 2 protrusion, (c) No. 3 protrusion, and (d) No. 4 protrusion

sec.title: 5.1 Frequency measurement
sec.p:
The prototype motor which shown in Fig. 10 is fabricated with materials present in Section 4.1 and geometries listed in Table 2. Impedance analyser (Agilent 4294 A) is employed to measure the actual resonance frequency of the motor. The analytical, FEM, and actual measured results are listed in Table 3. As shown in Table 3, the working frequency of the motor calculated by FEM fairly match the measured value, and the working frequency calculated by the analytical method provided in this article is close to the measured one. The main factor of the error with respect to the analytical solution is that the account of the adhesive layer between the substrate and the piezoelectric ceramic has not been taken in analytical calculation. In addition, error is also brought about from the geometry parameters equivalent of the piezoelectric vibrator. Fig. 10
The prototype of the piezoelectric motor Table 3
Resonance frequency results of the piezoelectric vibrator
Mode (a) Analytic (kHz) (b) FEM (kHz) (c) Measure (kHz) Difference (a)/(b) (%) Difference (a)/(c) (%) Difference (b)/(c) (%)
B32 46.02 43.32 42.34 6.23 8.69 2.31
B23 47.07 43.56 44.58 8.06 5.58 −2.29

Adhesive layer has been ignored in mostly literatures on analytical calculation of piezoelectric vibrator. The stiffness of adhesive is much smaller compared with that of the substrate and piezoelectric layer. Therefore, the stiffness of the piezoelectric vibrator without considering the adhesive layer will be larger than actual value, and the analytical calculated frequency will be enlarged accordingly. Consequently, the analytical calculated frequency presented in this study should be properly decreased to agree with to the actual value, and the rate of decrease should be 5–10 per cent according to the usage of adhesive. Then, the analytical solution can be used for an initial estimate of the motor's structural design.

sec.title: 5.2 Rotation speed measurement
sec.p:
Figure 11 illustrates the schematic experiment system for measuring the motor. NI LabView software is employed to program a sine wave with adjustable amplitude and frequency which is digital–analogue transformed by data acquisition card (NI PCI-6229), and voltage amplified by power amplifier (YOKOGAWA 7058) to encourage the piezoelectric ceramic. Incremental optical encoder (AVAGO, HEDS-9140-A00) is used to measure the rotation speed of the sphere. Fig. 11
Schematic of the piezoelectric motor measurement system

The prototype is placed on a sponge to roughly work in free vibration. When the driving voltage is 50 V, the measuring result between rotation speed and driving frequency is shown in Fig. 12. The sphere rotates around the y-axis during 42–44 kHz and rotates around the x-axis during 45–48 kHz. When the driving frequency is 44 kHz, the rotation speed around the y-axis is 5.78 r/min, equivalent to a linear velocity of 7.69 mm/s for the sphere. In the microscopic range, the arc length prodded by the protrusion in each step is 1.77 × 10−7 m since the time interval of each step is very short (about 2.3 × 10−5 s) due to the motor's high excitation frequency. By summarizing the analysis mentioned in the former section, the contact point moves through a quarter size of the elliptical trajectory from contacting with the sphere to the separation in every drive step. Combining the simulation results of the contact point's displacement in xyz-directions, the total length of a quarter size of the elliptical trajectory is 1.56 × 10−7 m. The simulation value of the contact point's displacement is the same as the one calculated in the experiment. This confirms the mainly results obtained from the finite element analysis. Fig. 12
Rotation of the piezoelectric motor at different frequencies

Figure 13 illustrates the relationship between rotation speed and driving voltage under 44 kHz exciting frequency. The rotation speed increases with the increasing in driving voltage. The rotation speed is 37.7 r/min under driving voltage 90 V. The measuring results demonstrate the feasibility of the motor design. Fig. 13
Rotation of the piezoelectric motor at different drive voltages

sec.title: 5.3 Torque performance
sec.p:
The rig for measuring load characteristics is shown in Fig. 14. A hose is used to connect the sphere and the loading equipment to reduce the reaction behaviour from the loading unit. Load torque is applied by weight attached to a string that is reeled using a pulley. The preload between the stator and rotor is only the gravity of the rotor during the experiment, which is 0.65 N. Load performance of the motor is measured under 80 V drive voltage at 44 kHz. The result is shown in Fig. 15. It can be seen that the rotation speed decreases as the torque increases. When the system is free of loading, the rotation speeds are 27.5 r/min around x-axis and 31.9 r/min around y-axis, respectively; the starting torques around x- and y-axes are 1.2 and 1.15 mNm, respectively. There is minor difference in terms of performance under these two rotating conditions. This is because of the asymmetric structure and the manufacturing precision of the spacing between the two groups of protrusions, since contact difference between the protrusions and the rotor in x- and y-directions will arise if the four protrusions are not arranged exactly in a symmetrical manner. Therefore, the spacing dimensions should be accurately guaranteed in the motor fabrication. Fig. 14
Measurement device for the load characteristics Fig. 15
Load characteristics of the piezoelectric motor around x- and y-axes at 80 V

sec.title: 5.4 Discussion
sec.p: The feasibility of the proposed piezoelectric motor is confirmed. However, there are still some problems which need to be solved in order to improve the characteristics of the piezoelectric motor. These problems and the corresponding solutions are listed blow.

First, an appropriate device should be designed to apply preload force on the rotor. As it is known, the output torque is proportional to the driving force and the moment arm and the driving force is proportional to the preload force and the frictional coefficient. Thus, properly enlarged preload will result in an increase of the output torque. Magnetic force can be used for pre-loading since the sphere is magnetic while the substrate and the ceramic are non-magnetic. Furthermore, the magnetic force is a non-contact approach which avoids the interference caused by direct contact with the sphere.

Second, stable support for the stator should be explored to replace the existing free support. There are four points located at the intersection of four nodal lines closed to the border of the plate. Since they are relatively static to the four protrusions at both B32 and B23 modes, the stator and external base can be joined with them. The support provided by four point-joints will ensure the stability of this motor with negligible influence on the vibration of the rectangular plate.

Third, a compact sensing device, which is able to measure the spherical motion of the rotor, should be developed in order to be integrated with the motor, thus establishing a closed-loop control system. High-speed camera employed in reference [9] or commonly adopted optical encoder is not conducive for integration. A laser sensor similar to the application in the mouse may be meaningful since it is small and cost-efficient, and the displacement in two orthogonal directions can be resolved in a single measurement point.
These problems mentioned above will be highly expectedly solved and the performance of the two-degree-of-freedom piezoelectric motor will be improved, making it more practical in further research.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A novel two-degree-of-freedom piezoelectric motor has been designed and prototyped using single plate vibrator. Two vibration modes, B32 and B23, are applied to drive the sphere generating two rotation degrees of freedom around two orthogonal axes. The working frequency of the two-DOF piezoelectric motor has been analytically calculated based on beam functional combination method. Expressions for determining the structural size of the piezoelectric vibrator, the position, and the dimensions of the protrusions are derived. Numerical analysis of the piezoelectric vibrator using FEM has shown the possibility to achieve timing reasonable elliptic trajectory of contact point movement. The deformation of protrusions supporting the sphere is about 22 per cent of that of those driving the sphere, verifying the feasibility of the working principle for the motor.

An initial prototype was fabricated according to analytical solution. Analytical and finite element analysis results are verified by experiments. It is shown from the testing results that the numerical results of modal frequencies of the motor are in well agreement with the FEM and experimental one, and the analytical solution can be used for the initial estimation for the motor's structural design after proper processing. In addition, the performance of the prototype is measured. The maximum rotation speed around the x-axis is 37.7 r/min under drive voltage 90 V and the excitation frequency 44 kHz. Torque performance of the motor is also examined.

The developed two-DOF piezoelectric motor has been optimized from commonly multiple piezoelectric elements into a single piezoelectric element which is compact, easy to be fabricated, assembled, and easily controlled. A sphere two to three times the volume of the stator can be rotated by the proposed motor. Therefore, it is feasible for miniaturization and offers a wide range of engineering applications.
